Social Sciences Learning Area - NZ Curriculum Alignment

Comprehensive mapping of Te Kete Ako resources to Social Sciences achievement standards

Jump to Other Learning Areas:

ğŸ“– English ğŸ“Š Mathematics ğŸ”¬ Science ğŸ’» Technology ğŸ¨ The Arts ğŸƒ Health & PE ğŸ—£ï¸ Te Reo MÄori

ğŸŒ Social Sciences Learning Area

"In the social sciences learning area, students develop their understanding of themselves, others, and the world around them. Students learn how people interact with each other and the environment, and how societies work and change."

Te Ao MÄori Integration: Social sciences provide natural opportunities to integrate MÄori perspectives on identity, culture, place, and social organisation.

NZ Curriculum Social Sciences Strands:

ğŸ‘¤ Identity, Culture, and Organisation

How people see themselves and express their beliefs and values

ğŸ—ºï¸ Place and Environment

How people interact with and shape their places

â° Continuity and Change

How societies change over time and forces that drive change

ğŸ’° The Economic World

How people use resources and make economic decisions

Years 1-2: Foundation Social Understanding

Identity, Culture, and Organisation

  • Family & Community: Whakapapa & Family Stories - Understanding connections and belonging
  • Cultural Practices: Cultural Celebrations - Exploring different traditions

Place and Environment

  • Special Places: My Special Places - Understanding place significance
  • Local Environment: Neighbourhood Study - Observing local features

Continuity and Change

  • Personal History: My Life Timeline - Understanding personal change
  • Past and Present: Then and Now Comparisons - Simple historical concepts

Years 3-4: Developing Social Awareness

Identity, Culture, and Organisation

  • Cultural Diversity: Cultural Groups in New Zealand - Understanding diversity in communities
  • Roles and Responsibilities: Community Roles - How people contribute to society

Place and Environment

  • Geographic Features: New Zealand Geography - Physical and human features
  • Environmental Care: Environmental Guardianship - Caring for our environment

Continuity and Change

  • Local History: Our Area's History - How local places have changed
  • Traditional Life: Life in Earlier Times - Comparing past and present lifestyles

Years 5-6: Critical Social Thinking

Identity, Culture, and Organisation

  • Rights and Responsibilities: Rights and Responsibilities - Understanding citizenship concepts
  • Cultural Values: Comparing Value Systems - Different cultural perspectives

Place and Environment

  • Resource Management: Sustainable Resource Use - Environmental decision-making
  • Human-Environment Interaction: Human Environmental Impact - How people change places

Continuity and Change

  • Significant Events: Treaty of Waitangi - Understanding foundational historical events
  • Social Change: People Power for Change - How ordinary people create change

The Economic World

  • Needs and Wants: Making Economic Choices - Understanding economic decisions
  • Work and Economy: How Our Economy Works - Basic economic concepts

Years 7-8: Advanced Social Analysis

Identity, Culture, and Organisation

  • Community Participation: Tino Rangatiratanga Arguments - Collective action and self-determination
  • Social Justice: Housing Affordability Crisis - Contemporary community challenges
  • Political Analysis: Political Cartoon Analysis - Understanding different perspectives on issues

Continuity and Change

  • Multiple Perspectives: Dawn Raids Historical Context - Different community experiences
  • Historical Analysis: New Zealand Wars Strategy - MÄori and PÄkehÄ perspectives
  • Decolonisation: Unit 2: Decolonized History - Alternative historical narratives

Place and Environment

  • Environmental Knowledge: Traditional Ecological Indicators - MÄori environmental knowledge
  • Cultural Geography: MÄori Astronomy & Navigation - Cultural relationship to landscape
  • Global Connections: Unit 5: Global Connections - Place in global context

The Economic World

  • Economic Justice: Unit 4: Economic Justice - Understanding economic inequality
  • Economic Analysis: Wealth Inequality Analysis - Critical economic thinking
  • Future Economics: Gig Economy Impact - Changing economic systems

ğŸ¯ Te Kete Ako Signature Social Sciences Units

Unit 1: Te Ao MÄori

Focus: Identity, Culture, and Organisation

Deep exploration of MÄori worldview, tikanga, and contemporary relevance. Students develop cultural competency and understanding of indigenous perspectives.

Unit 2: Decolonized History

Focus: Continuity and Change

Alternative narratives of New Zealand history that center indigenous voices and challenge colonial perspectives on historical events.

Unit 4: Economic Justice

Focus: The Economic World

Critical analysis of wealth inequality, economic systems, and sustainable alternatives that prioritize community wellbeing.

Unit 5: Global Connections

Focus: Place and Environment

Understanding New Zealand's place in the Pacific and world, including climate change, migration, and cultural exchange.

ğŸ” Social Sciences Inquiry Skills

Asking Questions

Students learn to ask meaningful questions about social phenomena, using both Western and indigenous inquiry frameworks.

Gathering Information

Students collect information from diverse sources, including oral histories, traditional knowledge, and contemporary research.

Examining Perspectives

Students analyze multiple viewpoints, particularly emphasizing marginalized and indigenous perspectives often missing from mainstream narratives.

Considering Values

Students explore how values shape social decisions and learn to articulate their own values in relation to social issues.

ğŸ”— Cross-Curricular Social Sciences Connections

ğŸ“– Social Sciences + English

Historical narratives, persuasive writing about social issues, analyzing texts for cultural perspectives, research and communication skills

ğŸ“Š Social Sciences + Mathematics

Statistical analysis of social data, demographic studies, economic modeling, interpreting graphs and trends

ğŸ”¬ Social Sciences + Science

Environmental issues and policy, climate change impacts, traditional ecological knowledge, sustainability science

ğŸ’» Social Sciences + Technology

Digital citizenship, technology's impact on society, data sovereignty, AI ethics and social justice

ğŸ† Assessment Strategies for Social Sciences

Inquiry-Based Projects

Students investigate real social issues using social sciences inquiry methods, presenting findings to authentic audiences including community members.

Perspective Analysis

Students demonstrate understanding by analyzing the same event or issue from multiple cultural, economic, and social perspectives.

Action Planning

Students develop realistic plans for social action, showing understanding of how change happens in communities and societies.

Cultural Competency Portfolio

Collections of work showing growth in cultural understanding, particularly related to Te Ao MÄori and multicultural New Zealand contexts.
